Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned all about the region known as the Balkans from the 1990s to present. About their internal and external conflicts and democratization.
This course developed my knowledge about Southeastern Europe, which I had not learned much about previously. It also provided a valuable foundation about democratic consolidation.

Developed a lot of interesting knowledge about Southeastern Europe and communism and its legacy throughout the region. Very interesting material. Also developed writing skills, both taking the exams and writing the critical case studies.
This class was amazing. The class not only covered past problems in the Western Balkans but current and possibly future problems as well. The class is highly applicable in the world today.

I learned a lot about the Balkan region's history which is incredibly interesting. Learning about the US and NATO intervention during the Bosnia and Kosovo war helps understand why military interventions were the way they were in Afghanistan and Iraq.
The course is extremely interesting, can be confusing at times due to material but great overall.

Professor Aldrich is extremely receptive to student feedback, and took into account our mid-course surveys accordingly. She was also very helpful in slowing down to go over particularly difficult topics.

The main strength of this course was that the material was extremely fascinating, and students learned a lot; furthermore, the professor facilitated a positive learning environment among the class as well. The learning environment was very positive with a classroom of only about ten students, and the professor was very willing to help students learn as much as possible.

Strengths: Great content. I actually learned things from this class. Expectations are clear, assignments are thought-out and balanced.
Weaknesses: Reading selections could be better selected, but this will come with time.
I would, it's very interesting and you learn a lot about places that are sometimes overlooked in other history courses.

I would recommend this class to any other student who has an interest in political science or history, especially since it is a region that still has a lot going on in the present. Even if a student doesn't have a background in either of these subjects, it is very approachable.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. Very interesting political science credit where you learn A LOT about the Balkans and the communist legacy throughout the region. While you learn some theory, you are mainly learning about the history of Southeastern Europe. Also, the work load is relatively easy, with only two short essays, a midterm, and a final. Professor Aldrich also allowed students to take the exams open-note, so as long as you studied the material well, it was not hard to do well on the exams. Great course!

Fantastic class. It was a small lecture, which sounds like the worst kind of class, but the format was incredible. It is an interesting class with an easy yet fair workload. Aldrich knows her stuff and communicates it clearly and with passion. Good class for both PLSC and non-PLSC majors!
I would definitely recommend this class to another student. The professor is great, the readings are great, the lectures are great!
Great class if you wish to learn more about Europe, communism in the Balkans and military intervention.
